Details/Description: Provides an important volunteer opportunity for Worcester South High students to participate in!
Notes: With the hard work and dedication of South High Students and charitable donations, we were able to provide new socks, new undergarments, gently used clothing and even new sneakers to teenagers and their families. Students sort and put donations on shelves, fill orders, write thank you cards, track orders that have been sent out, write letters to organizations for donations, and make phone calls to organizations to let them know their orders are ready for pick up.

Location of Organization: Mailing Address: PO Box 427, Barnstable, MA 02630
Website: Childrens Cove – The Cape & Islands Child Advocacy Center
Service(s)/About: Children’s Cove coordinates the multidisciplinary response to cases of child sexual abuse, physical abuse, witness to domestic violence, sexual exploitation, and trafficking. We receive referrals from investigative agencies such as law enforcement, the Department of Children and Families, and the District Attorney’s office for cases on Cape Cod, Nantucket, and Martha’s Vineyard.
Special Requirements: Serving Cape and Islands MA Residents
Who Can Request: When a child has made a disclosure of abuse a report to law enforcement or the Department of Children and Families needs to happen. Once they have received the report they coordinate with us and the non-offending caregiver to schedule an interview with Children’s Cove. In some cases, families may only have a question or would like their child to have an appropriate therapy referral. Calling our program will connect you to someone who can help navigate the best options to support a child in need.

Category: This is a curated database of resources is provided by Find Help Near You | Children's Trust MA.
Website: Social Services for 01605 (worcester, ma) | Find Help Near You | Children's Trust MA
Service(s)/About: Thousands of resources catergorize by need, search by zip code. https://ctmstaff.findhelp.com/
Who Can Request: Anyone in need can search the site for resources.
How to Request: View list to find ways to request specific needs. https://ctmstaff.findhelp.com/
Details/Description: When police or the Department of Children and Families believe a child is being abused, the child is brought to the CAC, which is a child friendly and safe place, by a non-offending parent or caregiver. At the CAC, the child tells their story once to a trained interviewer who knows the right questions to ask in a way that does not retraumatize the child. After the interview, a team that includes medical professionals, law enforcement, mental health, child protective services, victim advocacy, and other professionals make decisions together about how to help the child based on the interview. The child and their non-offending family are then offered immediate wrap-around services such as family advocacy, mental health and medical services. This is called the multidisciplinary team (MDT) response and is a core part of the work of CACs.

Service(s)/About:
Substance use recovery for adolescents. Embrace all pathways to recovery, ensuring that our adolescents are free from judgement and stigma while forging their chosen path to a life that is free of addiction.We are a support for Worcester County teens struggling with substance use challenges. Our services are of no cost to families.

We offer wrap around services including clinical support, skill building and healthy sober activities for teens who have experienced challenges with substance use and other comorbidity's such as anxiety and depression.  Our peer mentors and recovery navigators offer adolescents critical support during the non scheduled hours after school when boredom and peer pressure can lead to poor decision making and substance use. We offer services such as medication management, 1 on 1 and group therapy, art and music therapy, and a full recreation center for age-appropriate activities, groups, concerts and movie nights.

Our staff include doctorate level clinicians and physicians, Licensed Alcohol and Drug Counselors (LADC 1 & 2) and licensed social workers.
Who Can Request: Teens and adolescents
How to Request: Call 1-508-455-5053 visit website online request form www.4choices.org
Details/Description:
Alternative Peer Group (APG), Positive Alternative to Student Suspension P.A.S.S., Recovery Eductional Academy REA We are a support for Worcester County teens struggling with substance use challenges. Our services are of no cost to families.

We offer wrap around services including clinical support, skill building and healthy sober activities for teens who have experienced challenges with substance use and other comorbidity's such as anxiety and depression.  Our peer mentors and recovery navigators offer adolescents critical support during the non scheduled hours after school when boredom and peer pressure can lead to poor decision making and substance use. We offer services such as medication management, 1 on 1 and group therapy, art and music therapy, and a full recreation center for age-appropriate activities, groups, concerts and movie nights.

Our staff include doctorate level clinicians and physicians, Licensed Alcohol and Drug Counselors (LADC 1 & 2) and licensed social workers.
Notes: At Choices, we envision a world where every person has access to the resources they need to live a healthy, happy, and fulfilling life. We strive to create a world where everyone has the opportunity to thrive, regardless of their background or circumstances.

Details/Description: * Eviction defense and housing discrimination * Family law issues (divorce,custody, visitation, child support for domestic violence and sexual assault survivors) * Abuse and harassment prevention orders * Special education and school discipline issues * Employment discrimination and unemployment * DCF cases arising from poverty-related challenges (Hampden County) * Government benefits (TAFDC, EAEDC, Foodstamps/SNAP, Veterans' Benefits,) * Social Security, Supplemental Security Income (SSI), and state supplemental benefits, * Health care benefits (including MassHealth and Medicare), nursing home issues, and elder neglect, * Re-entry after incarceration (criminal record sealing, accessing housing and jobs) * Accessing homeless shelters * Debt collection and bankruptcy * Wills, estates, and Probate Court matters (trusts, powers of attorney, health care proxies, name changes) * Humanitarian-based immigration relief

Details/Description: A Commitment to Quality of Life: "As the District Attorney of the Middle District, also known as Worcester County, I am committed to helping our students and citizens of this district improve the quality of their lives and to live without fear of violence and be safe from crime. To that end, our office has created a series of community presentations designed to empower students by giving them the kind of information they need to feel safe and help them make good choices."

Name of Organizatio}BN: DETOX LOCAL: 45 AAPI ADDICTION AND MENTAL HEALTH RESOURCES
Category: Substance Use Recovery and Mental Health Resources Specific to the American Asian and Pacific Islander Community
Website: 45 AAPI Addiction and Mental Health Resources | Detox Local
Service(s)/About: We know that mental health concerns and substance abuse have increased since the onset of the COVID-19 pandemic, and this does not exclude members of the AAPI community. In fact, those concerns are at an all-time high for Asian-Americans due to the racism that has followed allegations that people of the AAPI community are actually responsible for the pandemic. These negative racial perceptions have led to increased general psychological distress, anxiety, and depression, and a high percentage of Asian-American individuals have reported direct racial discrimination due to the COVID-19 pandemic.
Who Can Request: Anyone - Specific access to the AAPI community
Details/Description: Within the AAPI community, cultural beliefs and pressures have made it difficult for Asian-Americans to reach out for help. Factors like age, gender, occupational pressures, family values, and dynamics, as well as religious beliefs and spirituality typically drive individuals away from professional care. It can be seen as weak or disrespectful to turn to a therapist rather than to the family unit, and even then emotions are not widely expressed or discussed in these communities. However, it’s imperative that those looking to quit drugs and alcohol seek help at a detox center to maximize their chances of getting and staying clean. It’s also incredibly important to be aware of common drug withdrawal symptoms. Once detox has been completed, it’s imperative to find a highly-rated drug rehab center

Some important specialty characteristics to take note of include dual diagnosis, pregnancy detox care, adolescent detox, LGBTQ sensitive, legal referral programs, spanish speaking programs, and detoxes that specialize in co-occurring health issues such as HIV/AIDS. The best fit will depend mostly on what one’s particular needs may be.
Contact Email: Theresa Buccico, Community Egagement Specialist, CPS Theresa.Buccico@spectrumhealthsystems.org
Details/Description: Recovery is possible! Walk in, call or visit website for Recovery Support by Peers and professionals.

Category: Addictions and Mental Health Resources for All
Location of Organization: 16 Best Reviewed Rehab Centers in Massachusetts | Drug & Alcohol (liveanotherday.org)
Website: Live Another Day: Substance Abuse & Mental Illness Recovery Support
Service(s)/About: Live Another Day was created in early 2021 as a response to the unprecedented increase in substance abuse, mental illness, and deaths resulting from the pandemic. We’re a small, tight-knit group of business professionals and clinicians who have invested thousands of hours towards creating a truly one-of-a-kind recovery resource. We’ve evaluated over 14,000 treatment providers throughout the country and only listed the centers that meet our standards for high-quality care. Many of us are in recovery ourselves, and our sincere wish is that this website gives you, the visitor, a second chance at life. Recovery is truly a gift and we’re here to support you.
Who Can Request: Anyone - Specific access to the BIPOC community
Contact Email: Other inquiries fill out online form at https://liveanotherday.org/contact/

Name of Organizatio}BN: One Can Help (Presented Nov. 2022 - ASK CASA)
Website: One Can Help - Foster children, At-risk youth, Struggling Families. Now.
Service(s)/About: To provide urgently needed resources to help underserved children and families take positive steps forward, in all types of juvenile court cases:  care and protection cases (abuse or neglect), CRA’s (children requiring assistance because of their disability or behavioral issues), Delinquencies, or PYA’s (aging out foster children), or cases where there is only just child protective services (DCF) involvement.
Who Can Request: All applications for OCH assistance must be made by professionals in the field. (Attorneys, Social workers, CASA, child advocates or other verifiable providers)

After your application is approved, we will work together to figure out the best way to pay.We suggest not to submit more than 1-2 applications at a time to avoid confusion. 24/7/365 Toll Free Hearing HOTLINE: 800-870-5905

Details/Description:
FACTS about Sexual Violence:
Chances are you know someone who is a survivor of sexual violence
The perpetrator is most often known to the survivor
It is never the survivors fault
RAPE is the least reported and convicted violent crime in the U.S.
Sexual Violence IS preventable
Healing is possible. Help is available.

Service(s)/About: Permanency mediation is an alternative to a contested court proceeding for children who are involved in the foster care system.
Who Can Request: Referrals are made through the Juvenile and Probate & Family Court.
Contact Email: For more information call Program Director: Julia A. Pearson, 1-781-433-0313 or jpearson@plummeryouthpromise.org
Details/Description: The model uses an independent third party to facilitate a child-centered approach to permanency plannning. By giving parents an opportunity to help develop cooperative plans for the child's future, permanency mediation both empowers and preserves families.

Service(s)/About: Meaningful connections are on the horizon! Our mentoring program connects you with staff, faculty, industry leaders, and community members to create one-on-one mentoring relationships. This unique program provides extensive benefits to students and professional development and networking opportunities for mentors.
Special Requirements: To become a QCC Mentee, you must complete an application. Once the application is completed, you will schedule a phone interview with a QCC staff member. After the interview, you will be able to browse through all our available mentors and select your mentor. You can also request a QCC staff member to choose a mentor for you.
Who Can Request: Students at QCC
How to Request: Drop in, sign up, and get a mentor all at once.

Name of Organizatio}BN: Rise Above Foundation (Presented Nov. 2022 - ASK CASA)
Service(s)/About: Rise Above funds individual activity wishes for foster children through an online application process. All children who are in the physical care and custody of the Massachusetts Department of Children and Families (DCF), are eligible.
Who Can Request: DCF Social worker, Child or young adult, Foster Parent, Other Support (CASA, teacher, mentor, clinician, etc.) *Please note that the individual completing the application MUST have the approval of the child's DCF social worker. Have their contact information ready to complete the application request.)*
Details/Description: Be sure to review the lists of what they do and do not fund on their website prior to the request.

Website: Sibling Connections – Enhancing relationships between siblings separated by foster care
Service(s)/About: Camp Sibling Connections in Maine, Sibling Socials, Weekend Retreats, Youth Leaderhip Program (YLP)
Special Requirements: We work closely with DCF social workers, caregivers, and other stakeholders to screen youth for acceptance into our programs. We strive to be as inclusive as possible, but our programs do not offer therapeutic interventions. We use the following guidelines to determine the fit for our programs:   ● At least two siblings living in Massachusetts in separate foster care and/or kinship placements (or adoption of one or more in the sibling group)  ● 7-20 years of age ● Interviews with the DCF social worker assigned to the sibling group for screening and acceptance into the program ● We accept referrals from anyone, but the DCF contact must be provided. To start the enrollment process for any of our programs, please email leslie[at]siblingconnections.org.
Who Can Request: We work closely with DCF social workers, caregivers, and other stakeholders to screen youth for acceptance into our programs. We strive to be as inclusive as possible, but our programs do not offer therapeutic interventions. We use the following guidelines to determine the fit for our programs:
How to Request: In Person: Stop by the Admin Building, Room 200A.
Refer A Youth - Silver Lining Mentoring

Inspirations | How Sweet it is

Service(s)/About: The Gifted Crate's mission is to deliver a customized birthday-in-a-box to as many children in foster care as possible across Massachusetts.
Who Can Request: DCF Social Workers identify children deserving of a birthday crate and submit a request to The Gifted Crate. Social Workers may email thegiftedcrate@gmail.com to request a birthday crate request form. Requests must be submitted two weeks prior to requested delivery date.
Details/Description: We serve foster children through MA DCF as well as military families residing in Massachusetts who have opened their homes and hearts to these children. Please follow us on social media as we share regular updates on our journey and crate deliveries.

Category: Scholarships, Grants, Outreach and Online Support
Website: Scholarships for Foster Children | The Jason Hayes Foundation
Service(s)/About: Established in 2005, the Jason Hayes Foundation works to support children and young adults who have suffered from early childhood trauma including mental, physical, and emotional abuse.The Foundation exists primarily to provide scholarships to children who will benefit greatly from attending a specialized camp or program to help them work through the after effects of this trauma and those attending a two or four year college or university. We also provide grants to camps and programs who work with these children and provide education for those who support them.
Who Can Request: Scholarships are most frequently awarded to those who are or have been in the foster care system, experienced early childhood trauma, abuse, and neglect. Need to be Massachusetts residents as well. Grants are available to another non-profit direct care organizations.
Contact Email: Jason Hayes Foundation, 284 Salem Street, Medford MA 02155, fax: 781-23209312 email: dot@jaysonhayesfoundation.org
Details/Description: Also see their information regarding grants for non-profit direct care organizations. https://jasonhayesfoundation.org/grant-program/apply/

Category: Resources, Enrichment, Emergency Aid, Home Modifications
Service(s)/About: Their services include providing emergency aid services, enrichment opportunities, everyday essentials such as toiletries and school supplies, access to cultural experiences across the Commonwealth, holiday gifts and more! They also offer the Wonderfund Access Card is like a AAA card created just for DCF foster families. Wonderfund partners with incredible organizations across the state to offer discounted or free admission to family-friendly experiences, including museums, theaters, outdoor spaces, and treasured destinations.
Who Can Request: DCF Social Worker is the only way to access Wonderfund resources.
Details/Description: Any child, aged 0 – 24, who is involved with The Department of Children and Families.

Service(s)/About: The Wandering Heart Project is to ensure foster and homeless children of all ages throughout Massachusetts have access to basic essentials and clothing.
Who Can Request: Anyone on behalf of foster children inlcuding Foster Parents
Details/Description: The Wandering Heart Project now manages donations from their warehouse in Rockland, MA and storage unit in Franklin, MA. WHP makes regular donations to foster children all over Massachusetts along with children experiencing homelessness. They have  also partnered with the Brockton WIC office to provide "Wander Bags" to families in crisis.

Category: School Supplies for children and families in foster care
Geography Served: Primarily Northeast, but can make arrangements to provide resources statewide
Service(s)/About: These backpacks frequently become more than a place for school supplies. They can also become a lifeline for children being transitioned into foster care, replacing the trash bags that too many children are still asked to stuff their limited possessions into.

Contact Email: Reach out to me personally through email, cell, or Facebook messenger on the WGYB Page, https://www.facebook.com/profile.php?id=100067779848128. Deborah Sweet dmsweet@gmail.com

Name of Organizatio}BN: WIC & SNAP (Women, Infants and Children) Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program
Category: Financial assistance with Food and Nutritional needs
Location of Organization: Over 30 area offices all across Massachusetts call 1-800-WIC-1007 or 1-800-942-1007
Service(s)/About: Visit website for eligibility form. It is recommended to use WIC and SNAP together as they compliment what items you can purchase with each benefit. Men can apply too and Foster children under 5 are automatically eligible for these services.
Who Can Request: If you are a father, mother, grand parent, foster parent or other legal guardian of a child under 5, you can apply. WIC is for all kinds of families, married and single parents, working or not working.
Details/Description: It is possible to start an application for WIC on-line by visiting  www.mass.gov/wic or the Mass Wic Facebook page, @MassWIC. Interested families can click on 'Apply for WIC' and submit some basic information to get thier application started. Or you can contact the WIC Program in your community to set up an appointment or call 1-800-942-1007. Many WIC Offices are open in the evenings and on Saturdays so you do not have to miss school or work. Walk-ins are always welcome!

Category: Evaluation Services for youth 7-18 years old
Service(s)/About: A program of Community Healthlink's Youth and Family Services including Mobile Crisis
Who Can Request: Court Ordered, Attorney, Case Manager, Family
How to Request: Julie Ann Lamacchia, LICSW, CJCC I, Program Director
Contact Email: Worcester Team: 1-866-549-2141 North Cental Worcester County Team: 1-800-977-5555 South Central Worcester County Team: 1-800-294-4665
Details/Description: Clients who are ordered by the Juvenile Court are evaluated by the JCC. Our service population is primarily children and youth age 7-18 who fall under the jurisdiction of the Juvenile Court for status of delinquency offenses. Since the JCC may also provide fornesic parenting evaluations pursuant to Care and Protection matters, our population served may expand from infancy to adulthood depending on those case circumstances and the nature of the court-ordered referral.

Location of Organization: Worcester Cultural Coalition 455 Main Street, 4th Floor, Worcester MA 01608
Service(s)/About: The Worcester Cultural Coalition ( WCC) is a public-private partnership established in 1999 between the City of Worcester and twelve cultural organizations. Today membership stands at 80 organizations, accounting for more than 2.7 million visitors to Worcester in calendar 2015, up from 1.5 million in 2006. Its mission is to draw on Worcester’s rich and diverse cultural assets to foster economic revitalization, support active, creative engagement for all and promote a strong cultural identity for Greater Worcester.
Who Can Request: n/a
Details/Description: Sign up for newsletter for Cultural events in Worcester County for all ages
